physicalObject: closed dark gray MacBook laptop
proxyLocation: bottom left of the desk
utilizationMethod: Use the MacBook’s hinged display as the chest-lid proxy. The user grips the top edge of the closed laptop’s screen (simulating the brass handle), then lifts and tilts it upward and backward. The laptop hinge provides realistic pivot resistance and a smooth arc, replicating the chest lid’s motion.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: A container that opens to reveal storage space for holding items
virtualObjectInfo.interactivity: Users should feel the lid's pivoting motion with smooth arc-based movement, potential resistance from internal springs or friction.
virtualObjectInfo.temperature: The brass handle may feel cool to the touch
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users will approach the chest and wrap their fingers around the brass handle using a cylindrical (power) grip, likely with one hand but optionally two if extra leverage is desired. With the handle gripped, they apply an upward and backward lifting force, pivoting the lid on its hinges. As they lift, they will feel the lid’s weight shift through the hinge, along with subtle friction or spring resistance at the pivot. Once open, they can hold the lid in place or close it by reversing the motion, feeling the same arc-based motion transmitted through the handle.

physicalObject: small silver cylindrical metal container
proxyLocation: front left of the desk, in front of the laptop
utilizationMethod: Treat the metal cylinder itself as the chest handle. The user grasps the container with a power grip, then lifts and tilts their wrist upward and backward. By fixing the bottom of the container to the desk with a small clamp or just holding it against the surface, they feel its weight shift and subtle friction, approximating the chest’s lid pivot.

physicalObject: closed dark gray MacBook laptop
proxyLocation: bottom left of the desk
utilizationMethod: Grasp the closed MacBook by its left spine edge in a full‐hand grip, fingers wrapping around the hinge area to act as the handle. Swing the laptop in an arc to feel its top‐heavy weight concentrated in its body as the hammer head. Tap the screen lightly against a soft surface or desktop edge to simulate impact resistance and rebound vibration.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: Striking and smashing objects
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: The hammer should convey significant weight concentrated in the metal head, creating a distinctly top-heavy feel. Users would expect substantial resistance when lifting and notable momentum during swinging motions.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: Thick cylindrical handle
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users will grasp the hammer’s thick cylindrical handle in a full-hand power grip, fingers wrapping completely around near the end of the handle to maximize leverage. They will raise the hammer by flexing the wrist, elbow, and shoulder, sensing the top-heavy inertia of the metal head. During a swing, momentum builds in the head and transmits down the handle into the user’s hand. On impact, users experience a brief but distinct resistance and vibration traveling through the grip, followed by the hammer head’s rebound as they decelerate the motion.

physicalObject: small silver cylindrical metal container
proxyLocation: front left of the desk, in front of the laptop
utilizationMethod: Hold the small metal container around its midsection with all fingers enclosing its circumference, using it directly as the hammer head and handle combined. Swing the container to feel its modest heft and inertia; upon virtual impact, tap the container’s flat lid against a desk corner to generate vibration feedback through the grip.

virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users will grasp the hammer’s thick cylindrical handle in a full-hand power grip, fingers wrapping completely around near the end of the handle to maximize leverage. They will raise the hammer by flexing the wrist, elbow, and shoulder, sensing the top-heavy inertia of the metal head. During a swing, momentum builds in the head and transmits down the handle into the user’s hand. On impact, users experience a brief but distinct resistance and vibration traveling through the grip, followed by the hammer head’s rebound as they decelerate the motion.

physicalObject: closed dark gray MacBook laptop

virtualObjectInfo.usage: Optical viewing device for magnifying distant objects
virtualObjectInfo.outline: Users should feel the distinct dual-barrel shape
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users will pick up the binoculars with both hands, each hand cradling one barrel in a light cylindrical grip. Thumbs rest underneath and fingers wrap around the outside. The index finger and thumb of their right hand will pinch the central focus knob, rotating it in small, precise turns. They will raise the binoculars to their eyes, aligning the eyepieces, and hold them stable with slight muscle tension in the forearms and shoulders. During use they may also adjust the hinge by gently squeezing the barrels inward or outward to fine-tune eye spacing.

physicalObject: closed dark gray MacBook laptop
proxyLocation: bottom left of the desk
utilizationMethod: Place the closed MacBook on the desk with a sheet of paper underneath to reduce friction. Grasp the two long edges of the laptop like opposite points on a wheel rim and rotate the entire device around its vertical axis by pushing one edge forward while pulling the other back. The laptop’s weight and hinge alignment provide continuous low-friction resistance, and gripping near the corners mimics spokes for added leverage.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This wheel would be used for manually operating industrial valves
virtualObjectInfo.interactivity: A freely rotatable structure around its central axis, responding smoothly to applied rotational forces. Users should feel the wheel's rotation transmitted through their grip points.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users grasp the rim of the wheel with one or both hands in an over-hand or under-hand power grip, fingers or palms contacting the circular edge or spokes. They apply opposing torques—pushing forward on one side and pulling back on the other—to rotate the wheel smoothly around its central axis. As they turn, they feel continuous, low-friction rotation transmitted through their grip, with subtle resistance from the valve mechanism. If more force is needed, they may grip the spokes individually to gain extra leverage and twist further.

physicalObject: small silver cylindrical metal container
proxyLocation: front left of the desk, in front of the laptop
utilizationMethod: Hold the container horizontally by its curved midsection with both hands, fingers wrapped around its circumference. Rotate the container back and forth around its central axis by pushing one side forward and pulling the other side back. The smooth metal surface and its mass approximate the wheel’s rim and inertia, and subtle hand-on-metal friction mimics the valve’s torque.

virtualObjectInfo.interactivity: A freely rotatable structure around its central axis, responding smoothly to applied rotational forces. Users should feel the wheel's rotation transmitted through their grip points.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users grasp the rim of the wheel with one or both hands in an over-hand or under-hand power grip, fingers or palms contacting the circular edge or spokes. They apply opposing torques—pushing forward on one side and pulling back on the other—to rotate the wheel smoothly around its central axis. As they turn, they feel continuous, low-friction rotation transmitted through their grip, with subtle resistance from the valve mechanism. If more force is needed, they may grip the spokes individually to gain extra leverage and twist further.
